rows.ODD-7: CONCEPTUAL INDEX: Deep definitions of key concepts (500-700 words each)
HOW TO USE THIS INDEX
This index provides deep definitions of the most important concepts.
Each definition includes: What it is, why it matters, how to use it, common mistakes.
For quick reference of all terms, see: Master Term Index
This index is for DEEP UNDERSTANDING of critical concepts.
CUSTOMER ACQUISITION COST (CAC)
DEFINITION: CAC is the total cost to acquire one paying customer. It includes all marketing and sales expenses divided by the number of customers acquired in that period.
FORMULA: CAC = (Ad Spend + Creative Costs + Tools + Labor) / New Customers

WHY IT MATTERS: CAC is half of the fundamental equation of business viability. If CAC is too high relative to what a customer is worth (LTV), the business cannot survive. Every dollar spent acquiring a customer must eventually be recovered through their purchases. CAC is the 'price of admission' for growth.

HOW TO USE: Track CAC by channel (Meta, Google, TikTok), by campaign, and by time period. Compare CAC to LTV - the ratio should be at least 3:1 (LTV:CAC) for a healthy business. Watch CAC trends over time - rising CAC is a warning sign of market saturation or creative fatigue.

COMMON MISTAKES: (1) Not including all costs (forgetting creative production, tools, labor). (2) Measuring too short a window (daily CAC fluctuates wildly). (3) Not segmenting by channel (blended CAC hides problems). (4) Ignoring CAC payback period (how long to recover the CAC).
RELATED CONCEPTS: LTV, ROAS, Contribution Margin, Payback Period
LIFETIME VALUE (LTV)
DEFINITION: LTV is the total revenue (or profit) expected from a customer over their entire relationship with the business. It represents the long-term value of acquiring and retaining a customer.
FORMULA: LTV = Average Order Value × Purchase Frequency × Customer Lifespan (or) LTV = Average Monthly Revenue per Customer × Average Customer Lifespan in Months

WHY IT MATTERS: LTV tells you how much you can afford to spend acquiring a customer. High LTV businesses can spend more on acquisition and still be profitable. LTV is driven by retention - keeping customers is almost always cheaper than finding new ones.

HOW TO USE: Calculate LTV by cohort (customers acquired in same period) to see if it's improving. Compare LTV to CAC - aim for 3:1 or better. Invest in retention to increase LTV. Use LTV to set CAC targets.

COMMON MISTAKES: (1) Using revenue instead of gross profit (overstates true value). (2) Projecting too far into future (uncertainty compounds). (3) Not accounting for churn (overestimates lifespan). (4) Treating all customers the same (segment by value).
RELATED CONCEPTS: CAC, Retention, Churn, Cohort Analysis, Subscription Rate
PRODUCT-MARKET FIT (PMF)

DEFINITION: PMF is the degree to which a product satisfies strong market demand. It's the point where you've found a product that customers want, at a price they'll pay, through a channel you can reach them.

SIGNALS: (1) Customers actively seek you out (organic demand). (2) High retention and repeat purchase. (3) Word of mouth and referrals. (4) Customers complain when product unavailable. (5) Unit economics work without forcing them.

WHY IT MATTERS: PMF is the prerequisite for scaling. Scaling before PMF is like pouring gasoline on a fire that isn't lit - you just burn cash. Most startups fail because they scale before achieving PMF. PMF is the difference between pushing and pulling.

HOW TO FIND: (1) Talk to customers constantly. (2) Measure retention obsessively. (3) Look for organic growth. (4) Ask: Would customers be disappointed if product disappeared? (5) Test pricing elasticity.

COMMON MISTAKES: (1) Declaring PMF too early (every early sale feels like PMF). (2) Confusing paid growth with organic demand. (3) Not segmenting (may have PMF with one segment, not another). (4) Ignoring retention data.
RELATED CONCEPTS: ICP, Retention, Organic Growth, Validation
